content.description:
Towards the end of the ice season, parts of Alexandra Falls can freeze up enough to be climbable.  Water still roars close behind the brittle features, so there are ... safety concerns.



Pull into the Alexandra Falls pull off a few kilometres south of Enterprise.  Walk to the right of the picnic area until you can easily scramble down to the river and walk to the top of the falls to rappel down.

Normal ice pro

The last ice route on the main wall.



Less than 50' past Lump, right as the rock of the main wall disappears into a slide in the oxbow.

You could protect it or boulder it

Another long, continuous wall of ice immediately to the right of Ol' Blue.  Short and solid blue most of the way.



Immediately climber's right of Ol' Blue.

Normal ice pro, lots of trees up top

A short, white and mostly vertical route.  It is right in the last notch/corner in the upper cliff band in the first oxbow (on the east end of the cliffs).  Once you walk past this route, you'll go around a corner in the cliff and see a long stretch of dry cliffs with greater tree cover on top.  There is a short detached block in front of it at its base.



This appears to be the last route on the upper level of the first oxbow.  The easiest approach is to walk in from the Escarpment Creek campground entrance (so heading east to west) along the trail along the canyon rim.  Keep walking until you're out of the trees and have a clear view into the canyon.  This route can be found shortly after that.  The top is fairly easy to spot, as it's a small, ice-filled clearing on the canyon's rim.

Normal ice pro, lots of trees

The lower falls turns into a gentle bulb of ice in the winter.  A fun scramble or beginner's route.



Rap down the upper falls of Escarpment Creek and walk down the stream.

Normal ice pro

A vertical flow forms immediately to the right of the falls itself.



Rappel down the upper fall and continue walking on the ice downstream.

Top rope with screws

Frozen waterfall in a beautiful canyon. Just a short walk from the highway. You can hear the water flowing underneath the ice. 



Labelled on apple maps as Twin Falls Creek. It’s just before you get to the Escarpment Creek campground when headed south from Enterprise.

Top rope with screws or from a tree

A white ice route that verges on becoming mixed.  A thick, vertical face leads to a little cave with overhanging features and an easier, slabby exit to climber's right.



Toward the east end of the first oxbow.  Coming from the Escarpment Creek campground, it is just past the first clearing after the trees where End of the Line and Kenny Sloggins are located.  It is directly between Kenny Sloggins an Lil' Blue.

Normal ice pro, lots of trees

A ridiculous distraction at the very end of the main wall.  Where the rock face splits off of what's behind it as it mergers into the slide, it forms a small chimney that gets ice flowing through it.  Wriggle your way up to victory.



The very end of the main wall, where the rock splits away from the canyon wall as it merges with the slide in the oxbow.

Boulder

A vertical flow of ice about forty feet wide tucked into a small alcove between the Main and Second Main Flows.  A corner of rock separates it on either side from these flows.



From the top, walk "left" (east) along the canyon rim trail from the Louise Falls campground until you see a clearing right on the edge with a bench and a picnic table.  The near end of the clearing is right above the far end of the Main Flow and the far end of it, where the picnic table is, is above the beginning of this wall.

Normal ice pro, lots of trees up top

A good, varied and wide route.  The main feature is about 30 feet of mostly vertical ice with a few ledges.  The wall of ice goes to climber's left for about 40 feet and becomes much shorter.  The shortest area can be bouldered and makes for a good exit to the trail at the top of the canyon from the first tier of cliffs.



At the far east end of the first oxbow, mostly in the same corner/nook as End of the Line.  From the top, it's easiest to find the top of End of the Line (icy depression right after you get out of the trees coming from the Escarpment Creek campground) and go about 30 feet further.

Normal ice pro, lots of trees

A short, deep blue route immediately to climber's left of the Eye. A vertical wall leads to an awkward, lumpy top out through bushes.



Immediately climber's left of the Eye towards at the eastern end of the first oxbow.

Normal ice pro, lots of trees

Climb anywhere on the short, fully iced-over face below the main cliff climber's right (east) of Louise Falls/the observation deck.



Below the main cliff to climber's right (east) of the Louise Falls observation deck by about a kilometre is a short, lower tier of positive, short ice routes.

Solid, thick ice for screws throughout

A short, lumpy, white route toward the very end of the main wall.



The main wall ends as the river and canyon bend into an oxbow.  There's a clearing and an overlook at the point of the land protruding into the oxbow.  If you see this, you've gone too far and need to double back about 200-300'.  It's around 200' past Deep Blue.

Whether you protect or boulder it is up to you

A single enormous flow of waterfall ice around 1,000 feet wide immediately down from the Louise Falls Campground.  Difficulty varies on where you climb it - it can be a gentle series of shelfs or vertical the whole way, so do what seems right.  The flow has two distinct halves.  The climber's left side is taller (about 80-100 feet) and is sheer vertical all the way.  In the early to mid-season, it requires a short mixed entry into very long chandeliers and only touches the bottom later in the winter.  Some parts of it remain uneven and can be a foray into interesting features and overhanging ice.  The climber's right side is more around 50 feet and has convenient rest ledges all of the way across for an easier ascent.



The main cliff face facing Louise Falls just down from the Louise Falls Campground - impossible to miss.

Easy screw placements the whole way or lots of trees to set up a toprope

A standalone small wall of solid blue ice about 300' down the trail from the little bridge.



About 300' feet down the trail from the little bridge from the top.  From the bottom, it's around a corner of rock from the Under the Bridge creek area.

Normal ice pro, lots of trees up top

The next very large, wide flow of ice down the wall from the Main Flow.



Accessed from the top.  Follow the maintained, obvious trail through the forest to the left of the playground for a couple hundred feet and find a convenient tree to rappel off of.

Normal ice pro, lots of trees for anchors

To the right of the staircase down to Louise Falls is a short wall of ice.  It's short with limited buildup for most of the season, but late in the season it develops into a few short but interesting features.



From the Louise Falls Campground, go to the right until the metal spiral staircase.

Bouldering with ice axes

The final very large flow of ice on the main wall below the Louise Falls campground and playground area.



A little less than a half kilometre going left down the maintained trail along the rim of the canyon from the playground.  If you hit the little bridge, you've gone too far and need to backtrack 150' or so.  Rappel off of trees to get to the base of the climb.

Normal ice pro, lots of trees for anchors

Sustained near-vertical waterfall immediately to climber's right of Louise Falls observation deck.  One of the best pure ice routes in the area.  



Access from parking area for Louise Falls campground.  The base of the climb can be accessed by going right (west) down the trail that runs along the valley rim to a steel spiral staircase and returning back to the area of the valley floor beneath the observation deck.  Immediately to climber's right of the observation deck for Louise Falls - another potential, less solid route exists between the deck and this route.  

Thick ice takes screws all the way up, trees up top for anchors.

Past Third Main, the wall the Main Flows are on curves into a new, shorter section.  Right at this curve is a thick, blue flow coming out of a little creek up top.



After walking past the Main Flows, you'll come to a little bridge over a small creek.  Follow the creek path down to the cliff, find a convenient rappel tree.

Normal ice pro, lots of trees for anchors

Probably the best easy-moderate route in the park.  A deep blue layered cascade of ice towards the east end of the first oxbow.



Approaching from the Escarpment Creek campground, it is couple hundred meters past the start of the ice climbing at the east end of the first oxbow.  From this same direction, it is in its own rock corner past the Eye area.

Normal ice pro, lots of trees

The white ice flow immediately right of the deep blue flow of Under the Bridge.  This one goes up in a series of waves that are not quite two body lengths each.



From the top, heading east from the Louise Falls campground, go over the little bridge that the creek forming Under the Bridge is under.  Turn right and into the trees about 20-30 feet past this.

Normal ice pro, lots of trees up top

This Territorial Park is run and maintained by the Government of the Northwest Territories and contains a steep, rocky valley with two waterfalls. The rock quality is poor, chossy, and largely unusable, but in the winter it becomes kilometres of ice climbing. Established routes are currently limited, but there is potential for significant development. The park contains campgrounds with sites that can be reserved through the territorial park system's website. In winter, the campground is unmaintained, but camping there is free.

Routes are slowly being added in since the area is still being explored and developed.  The canyon and the climbing area runs from Alexandra Falls in the west to Escarpment Creek in the east.  A trail runs from Alexandra Falls to Escarpment Creek along the north side of the canyon and provides easy access to the whole canyon and its climbing.  Someone keeps this trail groomed in the winter, so it makes for easy going.  Getting off the trail becomes a deep slog, however.  Escarpment Creek forms a small, steep canyon with its own waterfalls and drains into the second oxbow towards the east end of the canyon.  In the middle is Louise Falls.  There is a developed campground area by Louise Falls that goes right up to the edge of the canyon.  In the winter, the Alexandra Falls pull off is plowed and open, but it is far from most of the area's climbing.  The entrance to the Louise Falls campground is plowed for most of the winter and it's the easiest way to access the most concentrated ice climbing.  Most day hikers come in through here and keep a well-broken trail from the entrance to the trail along the canyon rim.  Escarpment Creek also has a campground, but its entrance is not plowed in the winter and gets deeply snowed in quickly.  It's the fastest way to get to the first oxbow, however.  Accessing Escarpment Creek for climbing can be done through the campground, but it's easiest from the road side where the highway actually crosses the creek.  It's a short hike down to the upper falls.  Rap down and walk further for the lower falls.  

It's not clear who did the FA of all routes.  Many are marked as unknown/uncertain, but they were probably done by a combination of JF Dufour, Eric Binion, Jeremy Dixon, and Graham Fournier.  If there was an earlier generation of climbers exploring here, please let me know.

Routes here are organized from west to east.  The canyon has a few clear subdivisions where the routes are concentrated:

1.  Alexandra Falls Area - There is a straight segment of the canyon that starts with Alexandra Falls and continues for about a kilometre before turning slightly.

2.  The Bend - A bend in the river between the Alexandra Falls Area and the Main Flows Area.  It starts with the bend from the first area and ends with a bend into the Main Flows Area.

3.  Main Flows Area - Immediately in front of (south) of the Louise Falls campground/playground area.  It's a straight stretch in the river from the Bend that ends at the First Oxbow.  Routes here are currently Under Observation through the Filthy Chimney.

4.  The First Oxbow - The first of two consecutive oxbows that follow the Main Flows Area.  Routes here are currently Waves through End of the Line.  The climbing area is a cliff that has two distinct levels.

5.  The Second Oxbow - The second of the two oxbows.  Escarpment Creek drains into this oxbow.

6.  Escarpment Creek - A smaller canyon that drains into the main canyon at its east end.  The creek itself has two waterfalls that freeze in the winter (the upper and lower falls) and some related flows around them.
